parser.error-invalid-date-format: "__str__"  is not a valid date; expected format: YYYY-MM-DD
parser.error-group-header-name-missing: the name of the group is missing (group: ....)
parser.error-group-header-name-empty: the name of the group must not be empty
parser.error-sql-invalid-relation-name: "__str__" must not be used as a relation-name
parser.error-sql-invalid-column-name: "__str__" must not be used as a column-name
parser.error-sql-having-without-group-by: having found but missing "group by" or aggregation
parser.error-sqldump-invalid-column-number: invalid number of columns in line __line__
parser.error-sqldump-insert-wrong-number-column: number of values != number of columns
parser.error-valueexpr-like-operand-no-string: right operand of LIKE must be a string literal

exec.error-column-not-unique: could not add column "__column__" because of ambiguity
exec.error-column-not-found-name: could not find column "__column__" in schema __schema__
exec.error-column-not-found-index: column index "__column__" is out of range in schema __schema__; index starts at 1
exec.error-column-index-out-of-range: column index "__column__" is out of range in schema __schema__; index starts at 1
exec.error-could-not-change-rel-alias-ambigui: could not set relation alias "__alias__" because of ambiguity
exec.error-could-not-rename-ambiguity: could not set new name "__newName__" for "__oldName__" because of ambiguity in schema __schema__
exec.error-schemas-not-unifiable: schemas are not unifiable: types are different or size is different: __schemaA__  and __schemaB__
exec.error-column-not-in-both-schemas: column "__column__" can not be found in both schemas of join
exec.error-condition-must-be-boolean: condition must be a boolean expression
exec.error-join-would-produce-non-unique-colu: join would result in non unique column names; the following columns appear in both relations: __conflicts__
exec.error-datatype-not-specified-for-col: datatype for column __index__ ("__column__") is not specified
exec.error-function-expects-type: function "__func__" expects arguments of type "__expected__" but "__given__" given
exec.error-could-not-compare-different-types: could not compare value if types are different: __typeA__ != __typeB__
exec.error-function-expects-arguments-of-same: __func__ expects all arguments to be of the same type
exec.error-case-when-condition-must-be-boolea: the condition of a CASE WHEN must be of type boolean
exec.error-case-when-expects-results-of-same-: CASE WHEN condition THEN result END expects all results to be of the same type
exec.error-invalid-date-format: "__str__"  is not a valid date; expected format: YYYY-MM-DD

translate.warning-distinct-missing: DISTINCT is missing; relational algebra uses implicit duplicate elimination
translate.warning-ignored-all-on-set-operators: ignored ALL on set operation; relational algebra uses implicit duplicate elimination
translate.error-variable-name-conflict: name conflict: relation name "__name__" already exists

inline-relation-editor.error-wrong-quoted-string: string must not contain single and double quotes

messages.error-query-missing-assignments-found: only assignments found; query is missing Help - Assignments

menu.headline: load a Dataset
menu.load-gist-headline: Load dataset stored in a gist
create-own-dataset-text: You can create your own dataset and share it with others.
Learn more about it in the Maintainer Tutorial

group.sql-import-group-name-placeholder: Name of the group (imported from SQL)

modal-sqldump.description: Put your SQL-Dump here to create a group.

selection-content: σ a < b ∧ b ≠ c ( A )
sigma a < b and b != c A
rename-content: σ A.y > 2 ( rho y←a ( A ) )
toolbar.orderBy-content:
τ a asc, [2] desc ( A )
tau a asc, [2] desc ( A )
toolbar.and-content: σ a < b ∧ b ≠ c ( A )
toolbar.xor-content: σ a < b ⊕ b ≠ c ( A )
toolbar.or-content: σ a < b ∨ b ≠ c ( A )
toolbar.single-line-comment-content: π a, b A -- useful comment
toolbar.multi-line-comment-content:
/* this is a very,
very long comment */
π a, b A
toolbar.inline-relation-editor-content: create a new inline-relation using a built in editor

toolbar.select-content:
SELECT * FROM A

SELECT a, A.b, A.c FROM A
toolbar.from-content:
SELECT *
FROM A, B as b
INNER JOIN C NATURAL
toolbar.where-content:
SELECT * FROM A, B
where A.a = B.a or false
toolbar.group-by-content:
SELECT a, COUNT(b) as num
FROM A
GROUP BY a
toolbar.having-content:
SELECT a, SUM(b) as sum
FROM A
GROUP BY a
having sum > 10
toolbar.order-by-content:
SELECT * FROM A ORDER BY a asc, b desc

SELECT * FROM A ORDER BY 1, 2, 3

tour.welcome: Welcome to RelaX, the relational algebra calculator
tour.choose-dataset-here: you can choose your dataset here
tour.currently-loaded-datasets: these are the currently loaded datasets
tour.load-dataset-via-gist: you can also load a dataset that was shared via a GitHub Gist
tour.relation-attributes:
here are the attributes of each relation and their datatype
just click to add them to the editor
tour.ra-toolbar:
the relalg operators can be inserted here
or you can use the alternative syntax
tour.ra-statement-goes-here: the relational algebra statement goes here
tour.ra-example-query: this is a simple example statement using a projection, selection and a natural join
tour.ra-example-query-plaintext: this is the very same example using the alternative plaintext syntax
tour.ra-example-execute-it: lets execute it to see the result
tour.ra-example-result: this is the current statement and the actual result
tour.ra-example-operator-tree:
this is the operator tree of the relational algebra statement.

You can click on every node to get the intermediate result.
tour.switch-to-sql: you can also switch to the SQL editor
tour.sql-example-query: this is the example statement you saw before, this time in SQL
tour.sql-example-execute-it: lets execute it to see the result
tour.sql-example-result: the SQL-statement gets translated into relational algebra and you can see the operator-tree, the relalg formula and the result.
end:
You should now know the very basics of the tool.

You can find more information on the
• a short tutorial for users explaining the basics
• a complete reference of the supported relalg operators and the used syntax
• a complete reference of the supported SQL subset and the supported syntax
• a short tutorial about how to create a new dataset for others
